en.value: Have you planned what you're doing?
Talking about things we like to do on holidays - Verb patterns (gerund vs. infinitive), "Would like..."
Let's get ready by learning some vocabulary for some of the things we might do on holidays.
The best part of a holiday is trying the cuisine.
Would you like to explore the town a bit?
It's great to get away and relax.
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
It's great to get away and relax.
The best part of any holiday is trying the cuisine.
Malta was amazing! We ate well and relaxed a lot.
This means the speaker got a lot of rest.
Select the three words which mean "taste the local food".
We'd like to hire a car for the weekend.
Would you like to explore the town a bit?
Select the word in each sentence which means to use something temporarily.
We'd like to [h]hire[/h] a car for the weekend.
I've [h]hired[/h] a tour guide to get to know the real Lisbon.
Let's explore the city centre in the morning!
This person is suggesting we take a closer look at something.
Some people like "to go souvenir shopping" when they're on holiday. Common "souvenirs" that we might buy are "fridge magnets" and "postcards".
Do you want to go souvenir shopping later?
You want to buy something to remind you of your holidays. What do you do?
Being active on your vacation can be just as relaxing as tanning on the beach. Let's have a look at some fun activities.
He prefers going surfing in the morning.
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
Ian and Ash went snorkelling in California.
He prefers going surfing in the morning.
The activity in this sentence is done in or on water.
There are many more activities we can do in or on water. Have a look below to learn some extra vocabulary.
Sarah earned her scuba diving license during her trip to Mexico.
My dad went [h]sailing[/h] down the Croatian coast.
I'd love to go skiing in Japan.
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
My family and I go hiking in Scotland every summer.
Last year we went skiing in the Alps.
Select the activity which involves walking long distances across country.
Another activity we can do in the mountains is "climbing". This word doesn't always refer to the sport, though. We can also use it in other contexts like "to climb stairs", for example.
I went climbing near Québec last year.
She climbed the stairs as fast as she could.
Match the pairs of words / phrases.
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Ian and Ash are making plans for their holiday.
What shall we do? I'd love [k]to explore[/k] the old town.
Me too! Then we could go for lunch and try some of the [k]local cuisine[/k].
Do you want [k]to hire[/k] bikes and go to the beach this afternoon [k]to relax[/k]?
Yes, I really want to go [k]snorkelling[/k], too! You could go surfing.
I actually prefer [k]surfing[/k] in the morning when it's not so busy. So I can just come with you.
OK great! I was thinking, maybe we could take scuba diving lessons later this week?
Yes! Sounds amazing. I already love this holiday.
Listen to the dialogue. Which of these things are Ash and Ian going to do on their first day?
Match the activities with the place where we do them.
Use the image to complete the sentence.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
I've always wanted to go [k]s[/k][k]c[/k][k]u[/k][k]b[/k][k]a[/k] diving.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
It's great to get away and [k]relax[/k].
Listen to the audio and select the correct option.
We [k]hired[/k] a car for the week.
Marta went [k]c[/k][k]l[/k][k]i[/k][k]m[/k][k]b[/k]ing in Italy last month.
Would you like to [k]explore[/k] the town?
What do you love doing when you're on holiday? Describe the best holiday you've ever been on by recording yourself or writing in the box.
I went to Sardinia last summer. On the first day I went snorkelling and relaxed on the beach.

Sometimes in a sentence, one verb follows another. In English we have different rules when it comes to using two verbs together, but have no fear! We've seen lots of these already in the course, and we'll recap everything now so you feel like an expert.
In this sentence there are two verbs together.

The first type of verb combination is verb + verb in -ing form. We can use any tense for the first verb, but the second one needs to be in the "-ing" form after certain verbs. These are some of the most common verbs that can be followed by "-ing":
We enjoy spending time with our children.
The first verb is in the "-ing" form.
The second verb is in the "-ing" form.
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Select the words in the correct order.
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
We [k]stopped[/k] [k]eating[/k] in this restaurant because it wasn't good.
Complete the sentence: I finished ... my book.

The other type of verb combination we've seen is verb + to + verb. Again, we can use the first verb in any tense, but the second never changes its form after certain verbs. Let's have a look at some common verbs that can be followed by "to" + verb.
We decided to buy a new car.
I need to go to the supermarket.
Rachel doesn't want to come to the party.
Complete the sentence: He's learning ... the piano.
My brother wants [k]to play[/k] football, but I hate [k]doing[/k] any kind of sport.

There are some verbs that we can use with either "-ing" or "to + verb", with no change in meaning, like "to begin", "to start" or "to continue". With "to hate", "to like" and "to love", there is a small difference in meaning, but don't worry for now, we'll learn it later in the course.
They continued working on the project - They continued to work on the project.
We often use the verb "go" followed by another verb in the "-ing" form to talk about sports and activities.
My boyfriend [k]finished[/k] cooking dinner then set the table.
Modal verbs, like "can", "should", "will" or "would" are followed directly by another verb without "to". In this case the second verb never changes its form.
We can go to the party together.
Listen to the audio and complete the sentence: Grace went...
Fill in the gap using the hint.
I started [k]to play|playing[/k] the piano when I was ten.
My sister wants [k]to go[/k] [k]skiing[/k] in France.
Did you try [k]to talk[/k] to her?
I enjoy [k]spending[/k] time with my parents.

When we want to invite someone to do something, we can use the word "would" to make the question sound more polite. Have a look below to compare two examples. We're going to have a more detailed look at how to use "would" to invite people to things and to express our willingness to do something.
Casual: Do you want to go out for dinner?
Polite: Would you like to go out for dinner?
Would you like to go skiing in Austria?
We use "would" for invitations to sound more polite.
"Would" doesn't change its form, no matter what person or tense we use it with. In questions, we use it like a wh-question word at the beginning of the sentence.
Would they like to go out tonight?
Would you like to explore the town?
"Would" always changes depending on the person we use it with.
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
Would you like to get away for the weekend?
We always need to use "to" + "verb" after "Would you like...?" or "would like..." when we are talking about something we would like to do.
Would you [k]like[/k] [k]to stay[/k] a little longer?
We can reply to the question "Would you like...?" in different ways. Have a look at some possible answers below. Notice that we often use the shortened form of "would" ("'d").
I'd like to get away and relax.
He'd love to go kayaking in Canada.
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
I'd [k]like[/k] to go away for the weekend.
Would you like to stay a little longer? - I'd [k]love[/k] [k]to[/k].
She'd rather hire a car than cycle.
They'd prefer to take a train.
We'd [k]prefer[/k] to book a package holiday.
While "rather" is followed directly by the basic form of the verb, we need to add "to" between "prefer" and the verb. Have a look below.
I would prefer to book a hotel.
Match the beginning and the end of the sentences.
What would Monique rather not do tonight?
She'd rather not eat at home.
To form negative sentences we put "not" after "rather" and "prefer".
In all other cases, we put "not" right after "would". We can also use shortened forms in various ways, as you can see below.
She wouldn't like to go to the concert.
She'd not like to go to the concert.
Select all the places (X) where "not" can go in the following sentence.
They would [h]X[/h] like X to be away X this week.
What would Daniel not like to do? Select the most accurate answer.
He wouldn't like to get a tan.
He'd not like to go sailing at all.
He wouldn't like to go snorkeling.
[k]Would[/k] you like to stay at home or go out tonight?
I'd [k]rather[/k] stay at home. I'm pretty tired today. What about you? Would you rather stay in or go out?
I'd [k]love[/k] to go out but we can stay in if you'd like.
It's ok, [k]I'd[/k] rather not cook so we could go out for dinner. Where would you like to go?
I'd [k]prefer[/k] to go somewhere close to here.
I [k]wouldn't[/k] like to stay out too late, so that's fine with me.
Have another look at how we can use "would" in questions and answers when inviting someone to do something or replying to an invitation.
I'd like a glass of water.
I'd love to have lunch together.
I wouldn't like to meet with him again.
I'd prefer not to go climbing.
What would Elisa like to do tonight?
She'd love to go to a party.
I'd [k]prefer[/k] [k]not[/k] to meet with him again.
[k]I'd like to get[/k] a return ticket for tomorrow.
Christelle doesn't want to spend too much time planning her holiday. Type the missing words.
She [k]'d prefer not to|'d rather not|wouldn't like to|'d not like to|would rather not|would prefer not to[/k] spend too much time on it.
Henry would like to have his coffee black. Type the missing words.
He [k]'d like|'d prefer|'d rather have|'d love to have|would like|would rather have|would love to have|would prefer|'d prefer to have[/k] it without milk.
